case_name: Lala Shri Bhagwan and Shrimati Gopal Devi v. Ram Chand and Kailash Chand

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 764 of 1954 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 9, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2272 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 764 of 1954. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 9, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2272 of 1959.

facts.text: The respondents are the present tenants of the premises bearing municipal No. 863, situated at Jumna Kinara Road, Agra, commonly known as Putaria Mahal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the present tenants of the premises bearing municipal No. 863, situated at Jumna Kinara Road, Agra, companymonly known as Putaria Mahal.

facts.text: Predecessors of respondents were let into possession as tenants by the appellants, Lala Shri Bhagwan and Shrimati Gopal Devi, on agreement to pay monthly rent of Rs. 58-4-0, tenancy from Sudi 1 to Badi 15 of Hindi month.

anchor.surface_text: Their predecessors were let into possession as tenants by the appellants, Lala Shri Bhagwan and Shrimati Gopal Devi, on an agreement that they would pay a monthly rent of- Rs. 58-4-0 and that the tenancy would companymence from the Sudi 1 of each Hindi month and end on Badi 15 of the next month.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Rent Controller and Eviction Officer under s. 3 of the Act for permission to file suit in ejectment against predecessors-in-interest of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants applied to the Rent Controller and Eviction Officer  hereafter called the Officer , under s. 3 of the Act for permission to file a suit in ejectment against the predecessors-in-interest of the respondents.

facts.text: Officer granted permission by order on September 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Officer granted permission by his order passed on September 1, 1951.

facts.text: Respondents moved Additional District Magistrate, authorised to hear appeals, who remanded case to Officer for fresh hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then moved the Additional District Magistrate, who had been authorised by the District Magistrate to hear appeals against the decision of the Officer. The appellate authority declined to companyfirm the permis- sion granted to the appellants and remanded the case to the Officer for a fresh hearing.

facts.text: On re-hearing, Officer rejected appellants' application for permission on August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On re-hearing the matter, the Officer changed his view and rejected the appellants application for permission on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: Appellants moved appellate authority again, who ordered permission granted on December 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then moved the appellate authority again and prayed that the original order granting permission to them to sue the respondents should be restored. On December 9, 1952, the appellate authority ordered that permission should be granted to the appellants for suing the respondents in ejectment.

facts.text: Respondents moved Commissioner of Agra in revision, who allowed it and set aside appellate order on February 4, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then moved the Commissioner of Agra in revision. On February 4, 1953, the revisional authority allowed the revisional application and set aside the appellate order granting permission to the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants moved State Government under s. 7-F; on May 7, 1953, State Government directed Commissioner to revise order as need genuine.

anchor.surface_text: That took the appellants to the State Government under s. 7-F of the Act. On May, 7, 1953, the State Government directed the Commissioner to revise his order on the ground that it thought that the need of the appellants was genuine.

facts.text: Commissioner, pursuant to direction, passed order on July 28, 1953, cancelling previous order and confirming appellate authority's permission.

anchor.surface_text: Acting in pursuance of this direction, the Commissioner passed an order on July 28, 1953, by which he cancelled his previous order and companyfirmed the order passed by the appellate authority, granting permission to the appellants to sue the respondents in ejectment.

facts.text: State Government did not hear the two respondents, Ram Chand and Kailash Chand, before passing the revisional order under s. 7-F.

anchor.surface_text: the short question... is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government... is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order, the State Government did number hear the two respondents, Ram Chand and Kailash Chand, who were affected by it.

facts.text: Appellants sued respondents in ejectment in court of Civil Judge, Agra after permission order.

anchor.surface_text: After this order was passed, the appellants sued the respondents in ejectment in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Agra.

facts.text: Trial court passed decree in favour of appellants on August 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the trial companyrt passed a decree in favour of the appellants on August 31, 1957.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to First Additional Civil Judge, Agra; appeal dismissed on May 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents challenged this decree by preferring an appeal in the companyrt of the First Additional Civil Judge, Agra... the respondents appeal was dismissed, on the 30th May, 1959.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in second appeal held permission invalid as State Government did not give opportunity to respondents to be heard under s.7-F, being quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge... came to the companyclusion that the said sanction was invalid inasmuch as the State Government in exercising its authority under s.7-F of the Act, had number given an opportunity to the respondents to be heard.

facts.text: Allahabad HC allowed second appeal, ordered appellants' suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the second appeal preferred by the respondents was allowed and the appellants suit ordered to be dismissed.

facts.text: Previous Division Benches of Allahabad HC held s.7-F order is administrative, no need to hear parties.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this question had been companysidered by Division Benches of the Allahabad High Court in the past and the companysensus of judicial opinion appears to have been in favour of the, view that the revisional order... is number a quasi-judicial order but is a purely administrative order

facts.text: Single Judge re-examined and disagreed with prior Division Benches, relied on Supreme Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge was persuaded by the respondents to companysider whether the said decisions were right and he came to the companyclusion that the view taken in the said decisions was number right.

issues.text: whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 (hereinafter called the Act), is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order, the State Government did not hear the two respondents, Ram Chand and Kailash Chand, who were affected by it.

anchor.surface_text: the short question... is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government... is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order, the State Government did

issues.text: whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellants have come to this Court by special leave and so, the only point which falls for our decision is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

issues.text: what is the nature of the proceedings taken before the State Government under s. 7-F and what is the character of the jurisdiction and power conferred on the State Government by it; are the proceedings purely administrative, and can the State Government decide the question and exercise its jurisdiction without complying with the principles of natural justice?

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the question we have to decide in the present appeal is what is the nature of the proceedings taken before the State Government under s. 7-F and what is the character of the jurisdiction and power conferred on the State Government by it are the proceedings purely administrative, and can the State Government decide the question and exercise its jurisdiction without complying with the principles of natural justice?

issues.text: whether the permission granted to the appellants to sue the respondents was valid.

anchor.surface_text: One of the issues was whether the permission granted to the appellants to sue the respondents was valid. It is with this issue that we are concerned in the present appeal.

arguments.claim: Revisional order under s. 7-F is purely administrative, no need for State Government to hear parties.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this question had been considered by Division Benches of the Allahabad High Court in the past and the consensus of judicial opinion appears to have been in favour of the, view that the revisional order which the State Government is authorised to pass under s. 7-F, is not a quasi-judicial order but is a purely administrative order, and so, it is not necessary that the State Government should hear the parties before exercising its jurisdiction under the said section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: we have first to examine the nature of the power companyferred on the District Magistrate himself. There is numberdoubt that what the District Magistr

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme of Act, nature of power affecting tenant rights, prior authorities quasi-judicial, requires natural justice.

arguments.claim: State Government under s.7-F exercises authority in quasi-judicial manner, must give opportunity to respondents to be heard before passing order.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge came to the conclusion that the said sanction was invalid inasmuch as the State Government in exercising its authority under s.7-F of the Act, had not given an opportunity to the respondents to be heard. He took the view that in exercising its authority under s. 7-F, the State Government was required to decide the matter in revision in a quasi-judicial manner

court_response_anchor.surface_text: we have first to examine the nature of the power companyferred on the District Magistrate himself. There is numberdoubt that what the District Magistr

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on quasi-judicial nature and need for hearing, but single judge should have referred to larger bench instead of deciding alone.

arguments.claim: Permission granted to appellants valid despite no hearing by State Government, as prior Division Bench decisions hold s.7-F administrative.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellants have come to this Court by special leave and so, the only point which falls for our decision is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: we have first to examine the nature of the power companyferred on the District Magistrate himself. There is numberdoubt that what the District Magistr

arguments.court_reasoning: s.7-F power quasi-judicial due to statutory scheme protecting tenant rights.

arguments.claim: View in prior Division Bench decisions correct that s.7-F administrative; single judge wrong to disagree.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge was persuaded by the respondents to consider whether the said decisions were right and he came to the conclusion that the view taken in the said decisions was not right.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct Magistrate. That is why we think the Act must be taken to require that in exercising their respective powers under s. 3 2  and s. 3 3 , the appropr

arguments.court_reasoning: Prior decisions erroneous; confirmed by analysis of Act's scheme.

arguments.claim: State Government under s.7-F must act quasi-judicially and follow natural justice by hearing parties, as power affects tenant statutory rights.

anchor.surface_text: When a legislative enactment confers jurisdiction and power on any authority or body to deal with the rights of citizens, it often becomes necessary to enquire whether the said authority or body is required to act judicially or quasi- judicially in deciding questions entrusted to it by the statute.

arguments.claim: Obligation to follow natural justice inferred from scheme of statute and nature of power affecting rights, even without express provision.

anchor.surface_text: An obligation to act judicially may, in some cases, be inferred from the scheme of the relevant statute and its material provisions... If it appears that the authority or body has been given power to determine questions affecting the rights of citizens, the very nature of the power would inevitably impose the limitation that the power should be exercised in conformity with the principles of natural justice.

arguments.claim: Test from Ridge v. Baldwin: principles of natural justice apply based on nature of jurisdiction and power over citizens' rights.

anchor.surface_text: the test prescribed by Lord Reid in his judgment in the case of Ridge affords valuable assistance in dealing with the vexed question with which we are concerned in the present appeal.

arguments.claim: District Magistrate's permission under s.3 deprives tenant of statutory protection against eviction, hence quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that what the District Magistrate is authorised to do is to permit the landlord to claim eviction of his tenant, though he may not comply with s. 3(1), clauses (a) to (g) and that clearly means that the order which the District Magistrate may pass while granting sanction to the landlord has the effect of taking away from the tenants the statutory protection given to them by the scheme of s. 3(1).

arguments.claim: Commissioner under s.3(3) must hear parties, satisfies as to correctness/legality/propriety, hence quasi-judicial; extends to State Govt s.7-F.

anchor.surface_text: This clause specifically requires the Commissioner to hear the application made under sub-s. (2) within the specified period. This requirement positively enacts that the proceedings before the Commissioner are quasi-judicial.

arguments.claim: Act's object to protect tenants from eviction (preamble, ss.14,15), so permissions require quasi-judicial approach.

anchor.surface_text: The right conferred on the tenant not to be evicted, except on the specified grounds enumerated by clause (a) to (g) of s. 3(1), is a statutory right of great significance and it is this statutory right of which the tenants would be deprived when the landlord obtains the sanction of the District Magistrate.

arguments.claim: Single judge should refer to Division Bench if inclined to overrule prior Division Bench decisions, per judicial decorum.

anchor.surface_text: considerations of judicial propriety and decorum require that if a learned single Judge hearing a matter is inclined to take the view that the earlier decisions of the High Court, whether of a Division Bench or of a single Judge, need to be reconsidered, he should not embark upon that enquiry sitting as a single Judge, but should refer the matter to a Division Bench

arguments.claim: Revisional power under s.7-F exercised for ends of justice, requires hearing parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

holdings.text: The State Government cannot exercise its jurisdiction under s. 7-F without applying principles of natural justice and offering a reasonable opportunity to both parties to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme under ss.3(2),(3) makes DM and Commissioner proceedings quasi-judicial requiring natural justice; s.7-F revision for ends of justice partakes of same character, affecting tenant rights against eviction.

holdings.text: The proceedings before the District Magistrate under s.3(2) as well as before the Commissioner under s.3(3) are quasi-judicial in character.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that these provisions unambiguously suggest that the proceedings before the District Magistrate as well as before the Commissioner are quasi-judicial in character Further, the revisional power has to be exercised and a revisional order has to be passed by the Commissioner to serve the purpose of justice, because the clause provides that the Commissioner may make such other order as may be just and proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DM permission deprives tenants of statutory protection under s.3(1); must give reasons for revision by Commissioner who must hear parties and assess correctness, legality, propriety; imports judicial approach and natural justice.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the District Magistrate under s.3(2) requires adherence to principles of natural justice as it deals with rights of parties.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the jurisdiction conferred on the District Magistrate to deal with the rights of the parties is of such a character that principles of natural justice cannot be excluded from the proceedings before him. This conclusion is very much strengthened when we consider the provisions of s. 3(3).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permission allows eviction bypassing s.3(1) grounds, removing tenant protection; implies weighing pros/cons after hearing parties; revision requires reasons.

holdings.text: The revisional order passed by the State Government under s.7-F without hearing the respondents is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellants have come to this Court by special leave and so, the only point which falls for our decision is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial nature mandates audi alteram partem; failure violates natural justice, rendering order invalid; permission chain collapses, suit incompetent.

holdings.text: Prior decisions of Allahabad High Court holding s.7-F power administrative are erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the reasons given by the learned Judges when they re- affirmed the earlier view taken by the High Court of Allahabad on this point. With respect, we are unable to agree with the decision in Murlidhars case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act protects tenant rights significantly; permissions quasi-judicial per Ridge test and precedents like Associated Cement; policy of Act demands natural justice.

holdings.text: A single Judge disagreeing with earlier Division Bench decisions should refer the matter to a Division Bench instead of deciding alone.

anchor.surface_text: considerations of judicial propriety and decorum require that if a learned single Judge hearing a matter is inclined to take the view that the earlier decisions of the High Court, whether of a Division Bench or of a single Judge, need to be reconsidered, he should not embark upon that enquiry sitting as a single Judge, but should refer the matter to a Division Bench

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial decorum and propriety demand larger bench for overruling coordinate or larger prior benches; traditional practice.

precedents.case_name: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: revisional jurisdiction under relevant section is quasi-judicial requiring principles of natural justice

precedents.citation: Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Bhupendra Cement Works, Surajpur v. P.N. Sharma and another 1

anchor.surface_text: This question has been companysidered by this Court on several occasions. In the Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Bhupendra Cement Works, Surajpur v. P.N. Sharma and another 1 , both aspects of this matter have been elaborately examined, and it has been held, adopting the view expressed by the House of Lords-in Ridge Baldwin and others 1  that the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed and judicial approach has to be adopted, must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction and the power companyferred on any authority or body by statutory provisions to deal with the questions affecting the rights of citizens.

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd v PN Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: principles of natural justice apply based on nature of jurisdiction and power conferred to deal with rights of citizens; adopts test from Ridge v Baldwin
precedents.cited_holding: the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed ... must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction and the power conferred

anchor.surface_text: adopting the view expressed by the House of Lords-in Ridge Baldwin and others 1  that the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed and judicial approach has to be adopted, must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction and the power companyferred on any authority or body by statutory provisions to deal with the questions affecting the rights of citizens. In other words, in that decision this Court has held that the test prescribed by Lord Reid in his judgment in the case of Ridge 2  affords valuable assistance in dealing with the vexed question with which we are companycerned in the present appeal.

precedents.cited_proposition: test for application of principles of natural justice depends on nature of jurisdiction (Lord Reid's test)

anchor.surface_text: We have already indicated that the Allahabad High Court had companysistently taken the companytrary view and held that the functions discharged by the appropriate authorities under s. 3 2  and s. 3 3  are administrative and an obligation to follow the principles of natural justice cannot be imposed on the said authorities vide Narettam Saran v. State of P. 1 . Indeed. after the learned single Judge had held in the present proceedings that the view taken by the earlier decisions of the Allahabad High Court was erroneous.

precedents.cited_proposition: functions of authorities under ss. 3(2) and 3(3) of the Act are administrative, no need for natural justice

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench of the said High Court companysidered the same question once again and re-affirmed its earlier view vide Murlidhar v. State of U.P. 2 . We have carefully companysidered the reasons given by the learned Judges when they re- affirmed the earlier view taken by the High Court of Allahabad on this point. With respect, we are unable to agree with the decision in Murlidhars 2  case.

precedents.cited_proposition: re-affirmed that functions under ss. 3(2) and 3(3) are administrative, no natural justice required

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that these provisions unambiguously suggest that the proceedings before the District Magistrate as well as before the Commissioner are quasi-judicial in character Further, the revisional power has to be exercised and a revisional order has to be passed by the Commissioner to serve the purpose of justice, because the clause provides that the Commissioner may make such other order as may be just and proper.

In our opinion, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that these provisions unambiguously suggest that the proceedings before the District Magistrate as well as before the Commissioner are quasi-judicial in character Further, the revisional power has to be exercised and a revisional order has to be passed by the Commissioner to serve the purpose of justice, because the clause provides that the Commissioner may make such other order as may be just and proper.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the jurisdiction conferred on the District Magistrate to deal with the rights of the parties is of such a character that principles of natural justice cannot be excluded from the proceedings before him. This conclusion is very much strengthened when we consider the provisions of s. 3(3).

Therefore, we are satisfied that the jurisdiction conferred on the District Magistrate to deal with the rights of the parties is of such a character that principles of natural justice cannot be excluded from the proceedings before him. This conclusion is very much strengthened when we consider the provisions of s. 3(3).

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellants have come to this Court by special leave and so, the only point which falls for our decision is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

It is against this decision that the appellants have come to this Court by special leave and so, the only point which falls for our decision is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F, without giving an opportunity to the respondents to place their case before it, is rendered invalid.

We have carefully considered the reasons given by the learned Judges when they re- affirmed the earlier view taken by the High Court of Allahabad on this point. With respect, we are unable to agree with the decision in Murlidhars case.
